title: The countries that need tourism the most include Spain and Iceland and the Maldives
text:
29 shares 11
View
comments
There are some countries that should, in theory, always be extra pleased to see tourists - because visitors shore up the economy.
Warm welcomes should be more or less guaranteed in the Maldives, Spain and Iceland, among others, because so much of their gross domestic product (GDP) comes from tourism, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council (WTTC).
Statistics showed that exotic islands in general were the among the most reliant on tourism, with the industry in Maldives contributing to 42 per cent of its GDP.

It's the administrative region of Macau in China that's most dependent on tourists. It raked in $26.6billion from them last year and the tourism industry accounts for 43.9 per cent of its economy
Holiday favourite Spain's tourism industry made up 15.2 per cent of its economy in 2014, making it one of the countries most dependent on travellers.
But it's the administrative region of Macau in China that's most dependent on tourists. It raked in $26.6billion from them last year and the tourism industry accounts for 43.9 per cent of its economy.

The picturesque British Virgin Islands rely on tourists to make up a third of their economy's income, having taken in $290million in 2014.
The picturesque British Virgin Islands rely on tourists to make up a third of their economy's income. Visitors contributed $290million in 2014
Aruba, Seychelles and Anguilla are the next most reliant, with travellers contributing to over a fifth of the countries' income.
Iceland also relies heavily on tourism with 7.1 per cent of the economy made up by the industry.
Fishing, aluminium and electricity production make up the rest of the country's GDP.
Altogether, China and the USA took in the most from tourists in 2014 - $263billion and $458billion respectively.
However, in relation to amounts generated in other industries this proportion was significantly lower, with tourism contributing to 9.4 per cent of China's economy, and just 2.6 per cent of the USA's.
Although data was not available for all the countries, particularly those with political unrest, the countries that least relied on tourism included Moldova and Papua New Guinea, with less than one per cent for each.
Moldova's proximity to the Black Sea provides mild conditions, perfect for agriculture and food processing.

Iceland relies heavily on tourism with 7.1 per cent of the economy stemming from the industry
The island is also renowned for its extensive vineyards concentrated in the central and southern regions.
In June this year Vietnam announced it will drop its visa requirements for tourists from five more European countries in a bid to boost its slumping tourism industry.
Last year, nearly eight million foreigners visited Vietnam, but arrivals dropped by nearly 13 per cent in the first five months of this year to about 3.3 million, according to government figures.
